metadata.title: Biological Applications of Terahertz Technology Based on Nanomaterials and Nanostructures

Biological Applications of Terahertz Technology Based on
Nanomaterials and Nanostructures
Ruiyun Zhou, Chen Wang, Wendao Xu, Lijuan Xie*
Terahertz (THz) technology is now drawing increasing attention around the world, which has been considered as an efficient non-destructive, non-contact and label-free optical method for biological detection. In this process, nanomaterials and nanostructures have been constantly advancing the development of THz technology. Here, some latest applications of nanotechnology improving THz biological detection capability in the aspect of providing progressive THz systems, thus enabling outstanding detecting performance utilizing THz spectroscopy and imaging have been proposed, all of which will encourage broader interest in various fields. The uniqueness, limitations, and future respects of THz biological application based on nanomaterials and nanostructures will also be reviewed in light of recent development.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Terahertz (THz = 1012 Hz) wave, lying in the gap between microwave band and infrared band of frequencies, has gained wide interest in recent decades (Fig. 1) 1. Ranging from 0.1-10 THz, THz wave has the unique properties including excellent penetration ability in nonconducting materials, low photon energy and extreme sensitivity to water, which has been applied in diverse fields such as materials science, physics, chemistry, biology, and life science 2-4.
The low-frequency molecular vibrations caused by intramolecular and intermolecular interactions such as hydrogen bonds and van der Waals forces lie in the THz regime 5, which has great importance for THz biological applications. Biomolecules and the flow of conformational energy for state changes of many significant bioprocesses could be detected by THz wave without any markers 6. And it also offers structural and conformational information that is not generally provided in infrared radiation (IR), nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) and X-ray spectroscopy 7. Hence, THz radiation has the unique advantages that are extremely attractive for examining new aspects of biomolecular structures and dynamics 8. Moreover, the phonon energy of THz radiation is much lower than that of X-ray and thus it is safe for living body without causing any ionization hazard 2. Therefore, THz technology is emerging as an indispensable tool to biological sensing and promises to open the field up to the general public for future use 9. However, THz wave, so-called “terahertz gap”, is the last band in the electromagnetic spectrum to be explored due to the shortage of productive sources and sensitive detectors. The shortcomings such as the weak THz detection sensitivity and low specificity, are its
crucial bottlenecks of THz sensing applications in life science and biology field. Therefore, efficient devices or novel materials are in urgent need to promote the further development of THz technology and its wide range of applications.
Inspired by the innovations in photonics and nanotechnology, the remarkable properties of nanomaterials such as extraordinary quantum nature 10 and unique optical character 11 have renewed interest for the development of THz technology, enabling THz research to be applied in biosensing field 1. The versatility of nanomaterials and nanostructures enables fast and sensitive THz sensing (as shown in Fig. 2). And the atomically thin characteristic together with van der Waals interactions among the layers such as graphene and carbon nanotubes (CNTs) makes THz devices easy to scale down. In addition, great effort has been made in the past decade to develop prospective THz sources and detectors based on nanomaterials. A comparative table of the characteristics of terahertz technology based on nanomaterials and nanostructures with traditional terahertz technology was showed as Table 1. Several recent major technical advances 12-14 based on nanomaterials and nanostructures have greatly boost the performance of THz system and enlarged its applicable areas.
In this review, recent advances in the development of THz generation and detection promoted by nanotechnology are demonstrated respectively. And then, biological applications of THz spectroscopy and THz imaging based on nanomaterials/nanostructures are also presented. Finally, the challenges and future perspectives of THz biosensing and nanotechnology facilitating the performance of THz sensing are summarized.

sections.heading: 2.1. Nanotechnology-based THz generation
sections.text:

sections.heading: Journal Name ARTICLE
sections.text:
This journal is © The Royal Society of Chemistry 20xx J. Name., 2013, 00, 1-3 | 2
Please do not adjust margins
Please do not adjust margins
Current THz systems require THz sources with the properties of high efficiency, high power, easy fabrication, low cost and portability at room temperature, which are in urgent need for the efficient applications of THz technology in diverse fields. Traditional methods of THz pulse generation pumped by an ultrashort femtosecond laser mainly include photoconductive antennas 12, 15, optical rectification in nonlinear materials including semiconductor, organic and ferroelectric nonlinear crystals 16, 17. However, the limitations of these conventional THz sources such as small output power 18 and high cost 19, 20 make practical applications of THz wave challenging.
Because of the advances in materials, nanotechnology, fast electronics and lasers, many new THz generation set-ups with high performance continuously offer promising alternatives 21-23. Aiming to improve the efficiency of THz sources, specific nano arrays and elaborate nanostructures have been utilized for generating THz pulse with higher output power (from 80 mW up to 120 mW) and broader frequency band 12, 24. Employing well-designed metal nanostructures to confine a laser beam on a photo-conductive antenna dramatically increases the power of THz radiation emitted from the antenna 12. Patterning arrays of nanomaterials on indirect semiconductors also improve the THz emission efficiency of the semiconductors 13. As an important member in the nano material family, carbon-based nanomaterials have prominent electrical and optical properties in the THz regime 25. Some devices based on carbon nanomaterials can be utilized for THz generation with the advantages of capability of working at room temperature, easy fabrication in a low cost and broad frequency range emission. For example, CNTs can be used for THz photoconductive switches with high efficiency owing to their superior characteristic such as high electron mobility, high optical density, high thermal conductance and tuneable energy band gap 26, which is crucial to improve the THz emission signal. Researchers had found that THz wave could be emitted from CNTs under an applied electric or magnetic field 27-29. As is well known, the electron gas can be heated by an electric field, and the energy difference of electrons in various active states occurs in the THz frequency regime 30. When the applied electric field is strong enough, the charge carriers in CNTs can be speeded up to the energy level for the optical/zone-boundary phonons generation (Fig. 3) 31. Similarly, THz emission from CNTs can also be excited by magnetic fields, and the magnetic field intensity has a significant impact upon the electron energy spectrum of CNTs 32. It is worth noting that THz pulses can be generated from both single-wall CNTs (SWCNTs) and multi-wall CNTs (MWCNTs) in reported research 11, 33.
Besides carbon nanomaterials, silicon-based nanomaterials and nanostructures were also employed to generate THz radiation with high efficiency 24, 34. Driven by the development of microelectronics and micro-nano processing, silicon photonics has become a promising method to provide cost-effective fabrication with large scale and integration opportunities for THz applications 35, 36. In 2017, silicon nanowires (SiNWs) were also electrolessly etched on the surface of modified silicon to generate intense THz wave. Compared to the bare silicon, SiNWs (about 3 μm) were confirmed to enhance the localized surface plasmon and increase photon absorption, leading to a higher THz emission. The mechanism of THz emission in SiNWs is principally the photocarrier drift along SiNWs via femtosecond laser excitation. Additionally, the emission efficiency of
THz wave based on SiNWs is affected by the external magnetic field and the length of SiNWs. Recently, Harter and colleagues 37 have employed a SiNW photonic device to generate THz radiation in the range of 0.1-1 THz, with the power up to -55 dBm at 300 GHz. Therefore, all these findings demonstrated the potential of nanomaterials/nanostructures facilitating high performance of THz emitter will pave a way for wider THz applications.

sections.heading: 2.2. Nanotechnology-based THz detection
sections.text:
With the improvements in THz sources, it is of equal importance to develop highly sensitive THz detectors with fast response time aiming to meet the urgent demand to acquire effective information in actual applications 38. The application of novel nanoscale materials and corresponding nanostructures are providing new opportunities to significantly enhance THz detection ability. For instance, carbon nanomaterials including graphene 14 and CNTs 39, silicon nanowire transisitors 40 and semiconductor quantum dots 41 have been reported to improve the performance of THz detectors.
For early traditional uncooled THz detectors, the consideration between signal sensitivity and stringent requirement of working temperature is what scientists need to take into. Devices with nanomaterials or nanostructures are expected to address this problem owning to their remarkable quantum nature 10. Single THz photon detection was realized by quantum wells (QWs), and quantum dots (QDs)-based devices at cryogenic temperature 42. And QW THz detectors with large-scale array can be applied in biological sensing with high response 43. Recently, researchers 44 have used quantum well infrared photodetectors (QWIPs) as effective THz detectors with fast response time thanks to the intersubband transition nature in semiconductor quantum structures. In contrast to QWIPs, quantum dot infrared photodetectors (QDIPs) have attracted more attention for photon detection due to their advantages resulted from three-dimensional carrier confinement in quantum dots. For instance, they have intrinsic sensitivity to normal incidence light, high optical gain, long lifetime of photo-excited carrier, and low dark current 45. In addition, QDIPs using electrical confinement method 41 to obtain uniformity of quantum dot sizes can achieve higher performance of THz detection, by which the tunability of peak detection wavelength from ~3.3 to ~6.0 THz could be realized.
One-dimensional nanowire transistors are also attractive for modern THz detectors 46. By using SiNW metal-oxide-semiconductor field-effect transistors for THz detection 40, appealing properties such as tuneable frequency, extreme compact and low cost can be obtained. The performance of SiNW transistor-based THz detectors are dependent on the electron mobility, which can be tuned by the doping concentration, channel length and the swing voltage. Since such devices have great potential in THz integrated circuit, it is meaningful to explore their applications in the THz range.
Furthermore, the up-to-date THz detection devices with CNTs are also presented 47, 48. Recently, Ryzhii et al. 49 have designed a sensitive room temperature THz detector based on CNT networks. Dense CNT disordered networks composed of a mixture of the SWCNTs and quasi-metallic CNTs were used to generate collective two-dimensional plasma oscillations aiming to improve the detector responsivity at THz frequencies. In this case, the proportion of the

sections.heading: Journal Name ARTICLE
sections.text:
This journal is © The Royal Society of Chemistry 20xx J. Name., 2013, 00, 1-3 | 3
Please do not adjust margins
Please do not adjust margins
SWCNTs and MWCNTs has an impact on the detector responsivity, and an obvious increase can be found in the burning of the nearcontact regions of the CNTs. Besides, applications of graphene in THz detection enhancement are also worth mentioning. Since graphene, especially monolayer graphene, has unique properties that can be utilized as THz detectors operated with high sensitivity 50. Hence, graphene has been frequently studied in recent THz research 51 for its intriguing properties including the ultrahigh electron mobility yielding high conductivity, the strong electron-electron interaction allowing ultrafast detector response 52, tuneable surface conductivity properties enabling wideband spectrum detection 53, and exceptionally long plasmon lifetime enhancing light absorption efficiency 54.
Tong et al. 55 discovered that graphene field effect transistor (GFET) thermoelectric THz detectors through coupling monolayer graphene to a double-patch antenna and silicon lens were capable of realizing more than four orders of magnitude performance enhancement in THz detection at room temperature, which could be regarded as good supplements to existing THz detectors. In their work, graphene served as a THz absorber in the graphene-antennasilicon lens structure (as shown in Fig. 4a and Fig. 4b). As a result, electrons were heated up by the THz absorption and hot carriers generated in the system were accelerated, leading to the creation of a thermoelectric field, which dramatically impacted the THz detection responsivity. Besides, the detection sensitivity also depended on the direction of THz wave irradiating the antenna and silicon lens coupled with graphene. The signal intensity could be greatly enhanced by a factor of 2200 with the front illumination (see Fig. 4c). Furthermore, it is known that conventional transistors are restricted by the high-frequency roll-off. To overcome this challenge, Cai et al. 56 made a THz detector with high sensitivity based on singlelayer graphene microribbon, which demonstrated the feasibility of using sensitive graphene-based THz detectors to obtain richer information in THz applications 57.

sections.heading: 3. Biological sensing by THz spectroscopy based on nanomaterials and nanostructures
sections.text:
Generally speaking, the applied forms of THz technology are divided into two types: THz spectroscopy and THz imaging. Among diverse invasive sensing means, THz spectroscopy has been emerging as a promising tool to inspect biological samples 58. Since THz timedomain spectroscopy (THz-TDS) was firstly established in the late 1980s 59, it has been tentatively used for biological recognition including proteins 60, cancer tissues 61, bacteria 62 and nucleic acid molecules 63. Both amplitude and phase information of samples can be extracted from THz-TDS 64 through coherent light detection mode in broad spectrum. Besides, it is perfectly suitable for THz-TDS to detect large biomolecules dynamically on account of a high temporal resolution gained from the picosecond pulse 65. Due to the low ionization energy of THz radiation, THz-TDS, is regarded as a strong non-destructive testing technique to directly acquire the overall information including amplitude and phase, which are correlated to the absorption coefficient and refractive index of the object 66.
However, conventional THz-TDS, either with transmission or reflection measurement, is limited by the poor sensitivity. The strong water absorption also hinders real biological application in aqueous
samples of THz spectroscopy sensing. Therefore, new materials such as graphene 67, metamaterials containing nanostructures 68 and other structures 69, 70 can be utilized to overcome this limitation and to enhance the biological sensing sensitivity (see Table 2).

sections.heading: 3.1. Nanomaterial plasmonics
sections.text: Taking advantage of nanomaterial plasmonics to increase sensitivity is the intriguing progress in nanotechnology-based THz sensing 71. As is mentioned, graphene has been extensively studied for its fascinating electrical and optical properties 72, 73. In the past decade, graphene and corresponding structures have played peculiar roles as biosensing materials 74-76. Through designing graphene nanoribbon arrays with a certain size, graphene plasmons were observed in the mid-infrared 77 to THz region 78, which could be applied in nanoplasmonic THz devices. Graphene plasmons are very sensitive to the changes of refractive index 79, which can be utilized in biosensors. In 2015, Rodrigo et al. 76 fabricated a graphene-nanoribbon-based tuneable biosensor (Fig. 5) and discussed its potential ability to quantitatively detect biomolecules and discriminate specific proteins. As the successful application of graphene plasmonic biosensor in mid-infrared band and THz band has been promoted, tremendous potential of nanophotonic-based biosensors applying in the THz frequency range are very promising.

sections.heading: 3.2. Combination of nanomaterials and metamaterials
sections.text:
Metamaterials 80, as a novel type of compositional periodic artificial materials, are suitable for THz biosensing applications, as metamaterials with special specifications like size and shape can stimulate spoof surface plasmons and effectively interact with THz radiation 81. Given the extraordinary plasmonic properties of nanomaterials and nanostructures, the combination of metamaterials and nanomaterials/nanostructures has been investigated hotly in THz biosensing field.
A hybrid graphene-gold-based metamaterial structure was designed to numerically study the detection ability of its transmission curve and refractive index in the THz region 82. In their work, the plasmon resonance frequency is dependent on the refractive index of the ambient media, which is tuneable to the optimum band so as to make sure the full interaction between target molecules and THz radiation. And the dynamic regulation of operating frequency can be reached by adjusting the Fermi level to change the complex surface conductivity of graphene 83. The resonance frequency and transmittance greatly increase from ~8.59 to ~11.4 THz and from ~0.14 to ~0.75, respectively, as the Fermi level of graphene increases from 0.8 to 1.5 eV. Based on the graphene-metamaterial device, the accurate resonance frequency tunability and modulation characteristic contribute to the realization of high sensitivity (3.04 THz/RIU), which is very appealing for employing new-type sensing tools in THz spectroscopy.
Additionally, gold nanoparticles (GNPs) have been introduced to plasmonic metamaterial devices to enhance the sensitivity in the THz regime. For instance, Ahmadivand and co-workers 70 employed GNPs to decorate antibodies, so as to capture the target biomarkers based on a toroidal metamaterial structure, as presented in Fig. 6a and b. Ultra-narrow toroidal dipole resonances induced in the toroidal THz metamaterial were utilized to sense and quantify Zika virus-envelope proteins with low concentration. In this microsystem, colloidal

nanoparticles were in conjunction with target molecules aiming to study the effect of noble nanoparticles on the THz frequency response. The results indicated that the existence of GNPs could tailor the THz biosensors to capture target biomarkers with high accuracy and sensitivity. Compared to parallel devices, the sensing sensitivity can be increased by nearly 100 times with the GNPintegrated toroidal THz plasmonic biosensor. Other nanomaterialimproved THz metamaterial biosensor showed in Fig.6e-g 84 was also applied to protein detection with a sensitivity enhancement up to 1000-fold. All these findings highlighted the extremely promising characteristics of nanomaterials improving the sensing ability of THz biosensors.

sections.heading: 3.3. Metamaterials containing nanostructures
sections.text:
Integrating nanostructures with metamaterials is an effective way to greatly enhance the localized filed of the THz sensing devices 85-87. In order to achieve a stronger THz field and increase the absorption cross section of the intended analytes, Lee et al. 88 designed a metamaterial sensing chip in nanoscale, as shown in Fig. 7a. Rapid qualitative and quantitative detection of three subtypes of Avian Influenza (AI) viruses (H1N1, H5N2, H9N2) were performed attributing to the nano-metamaterial-structure. Through analysing the optical parameters including THz transmission, refractive index and absorption coefficient, three virus samples could be distinguished clearly, see Fig. 7b. Their results indicated that the nano-metamaterial chip could be used in THz biosensing with ultrahigh detection sensitivity and selectivity.
Besides, nanofluidic structures have also been introduced to THz biological sensing in order to overcome the hinder of water absorption of THz wave and realize a high performance of biomolecule detection 89, 90. The large absorption loss of polar molecules (usually water) in the THz region has always been a major obstacle for detecting biomolecules in water solutions using THz spectroscopy 58. Although attenuated total reflection (ATR) spectroscopy has been put into use to strengthen the interaction between target samples and incoming THz wave to some extent 91, novel structures are still in great demand for THz sensing in water environment aiming for higher response sensitivity and SNR values. Research showed that confining RNA sample solutions into nanofluidic channels could extend the lifetime of wave-matter interaction and make the target molecules concentrated, thus realizing the observation of a narrow absorption (10-GHz line width) 92. Recently, Shih et al. 90 have designed a nanofluidic THz metasensor utilizing split ring and Fano resonators as basic sensing structures (see Fig. 8), realizing the detection of adenosine triphosphate (ATP) with different concentrations in aqueous environment. Their work demonstrated that scaling down the analyte volume to nanoscale level could not only make for less absorption loss from water, thereby effectively increasing sensing sensitivity, but also aid in delivering the molecules to the sensing area with high efficiency.
Despite a great deal of effort made to promote the detectability of various biomaterials using THz spectroscopy based on the abovementioned distinguished approaches and new devices, the detection of biomaterials using THz spectroscopy is still suffering from small measurement areas and the inhomogeneity of the target biological samples, the detection results from which fail to represent the
overall condition. Compared with THz spectroscopy, THz imaging provides more visualizations via building up geometrical images, thus, enabling to effectively detect the biological samples with irreplaceable advantages 93. Thence, the combination of THz spectroscopy and THz imaging in a whole THz system will contribute to collect overall information for biological applications.

sections.heading: 4. Biological sensing by THz imaging based on nanotechnology
sections.text:
THz imaging has been paid particular attention and also been a very active topic in biological field especially for tumor and cancer diagnosis 94. As is known, THz imaging and THz spectroscopy are two main modalities of THz sensing, by which inherent optical features and exterior morphological characters can be expediently abstracted form the amplitude and phase information simultaneously 95. With the exclusive advantages of the low ionization energy of THz wave, sensitivity to water absorption and the THz fingerprint vibrational spectra for most biomolecules, THz imaging can effectively distinguish malignant tumors and cancers from normal ones with higher spatial resolution compared with microwave imaging in a relatively safe manner 96. Thereby, THz imaging is regarded as a promising and robust platform for myriad applications in the fields of medical imaging and biological science 97.
During the past two decades, THz imaging has been successfully utilized to distinguish abnormal tissues of brain 98, liver 99, breast 100, and so on 94. However, the relatively weak fingerprint resonant signals of biomolecules in the THz frequency range due to the disturbance of other environmental factors still have been an unavoidable problem for THz imaging 63. From a detection standpoint, high image resolution is in great demand for practical biological applications. With the advance of nanotechnology, several techniques such as nanoparticle-enhanced imaging and nano/micrometer-devices, have been developed to overcome the limitation in THz imaging.

sections.heading: 4.1. Nanoparticles contrast agents for THz imaging
sections.text:
Generally, the main mechanisms of employing THz imaging in biological applications are based on the differences of water content and physiological structural changes between abnormal and normal tissues. Because most biomaterials are indwelling in water environment or containing water, which makes it challenging for THz radiation to penetrate through biological organizations with certain thickness due to the inevitable absorption loss from polar liquids. But in other words, the highlighted absorption capacity of water that restricts the depth of penetration in samples also facilitates extreme contrast between tissues with different water content.
One of the essential functions of nanotechnology promoting the development of THz imaging is the use of nanomaterials including GNPs 101, gold nanorods (GNRs) 102, and gadolinium oxide (Gd2O3) nanoparticles 103 as contrast agents. In general, contrast agents are utilized to amplify picture contrast between normal and diseased tissues. Nanoparticles irradiated with near-infrared (NIR) laser can excite surface plasma polaritons (SPPs), which lead to the temperature rise of water. Since the temperature variation can make a difference to the THz signal 104, nanoparticles contrast agents are very helpful to improve the quality of THz imaging for bio-tissues. In a recent work, Moldosanov et al. 101 have taken advantage of this

sections.heading: Journal Name ARTICLE
sections.text:
This journal is © The Royal Society of Chemistry 20xx J. Name., 2013, 00, 1-3 | 5
Please do not adjust margins
Please do not adjust margins
mechanism to spot tumours. As is illustrated, the THz radiation irradiated a biological sample with the cancer tumour, which was also illuminated by the NIR laser in the meantime. During the process of laser irradiating, SSPs were induced by the NIR radiation from GNPs, which were delivered into the cancer tumour beforehand. Consequently, the temperature increasement of tumour made it more sensitive for THz radiation. Hence, the image signal of the tumour will be more intense and clearer for the IR camera.
GNRs are also utilized as a kind of potential THz imaging contrast agents for their localized surface plasmon character 102. The rise of the temperature caused by the heat production when NIR laser illuminates the sample with GNRs, would significantly increase the absorption of water in the THz regime 105. Hence, the detection ability of THz molecule imaging gets great enhancement based on the heat effect of GNRs and the succedent absorption increasement of water, which was used to distinguish preclinical epidermoid carcinoma with considerable sensitivity and accuracy. Besides, the use of GNRs for THz imaging would change the refractive indices of the target samples by the reason of temperature increasing, which leads to a 20% THz signal improvement by comparison with samples without GNRs. What’s more, gadolinium oxide (Gd2O3) nanoparticles are reported as another contrast agents in THz imaging 103, the absorption capacity of which is much higher than water in THz band. More significantly, the previous application of Gd2O3 nanoparticles as a Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) contrast agent conduces to improve the feasibility of novel THz-MRI imaging detection methods.

sections.heading: 4.2. THz near-field nanoscale imaging
sections.text:
Accordingly, tremendous effort has been made to facilitate subwavelength THz imaging in biological detection, such as utilizing nanoparticles as contrast agents, which can improve THz imaging contrast, thereby, reaching better imaging quality. Besides, combining near-field microscopy techniques with THz imaging can also create the possibility of confining THz wave to subwavelength resolution, by which nanoscale imaging could be realized. Therefore, with the development of nanotechnology and optical microscopy fabrication, THz imaging could realize fast and accurate detection of biological materials.
Researchers 106 found that nanoscale tips could be used to excite nano-sized evanescent waves, enabling to improve THz imaging resolution of biomaterials. In addition, strong localized scattering can be generated by a THz near-field, which extremely enhances the imaging resolution up to nanometers 107. Some specific structures such as subwavelength-scale apertures were fabricated to generate the THz near-field, by which THz imaging of subwavelength resolution can be implemented. Based on this technique, Chen et al. 108 made some improvement with metallic strips for imaging, which succeeded to be applied for biological imaging. Thereafter, Kawano et al. 109 designed an on-chip near-field THz detector to promote THz sensing. In this case, a metallic probe in nanoscale was fixed near the metallic aperture, which greatly improved the THz radiation detection sensitivity. In addition, the silicon nanotip arrays fabricated by Shi et al. 35, serving as THz modulators with low-loss and broadband property, has showed great potential for future THz nearfield imaging applications.
5. Conclusions and Perspectives
THz sensing technology has been gaining more significant attention due to its non-contact, non-ionizing and label-free properties, which is perfectly suitable for biological detection. However, the biological sensing sensitivity of a conventional THz system is still insufficient in comparison with other common standard technologies. It is in urgent need of boosting the intrinsic performance of THz sources and THz detectors, and great effort needs to be made to break the existing limitations of THz technology to achieve more widespread applications.
While the development of nanotechnology has been creating more possibilities for employing THz sensing in biological field. The interface between nanoscience and THz technology are promoting the practical biosensing applications in the THz frequency range. Overall, nanomaterials and nanostructures contribute to improve the performance of THz systems and overcome essential THz detecting limitations in THz biosensing, such as poor sensitivity, low accuracy, small penetration depth, coarse spatial resolution, and high operating costs.
It is no doubt that the use of nanomaterials and nanostructures have opened up a new situation for THz biological applications. Firstly, high-performance THz sources and detectors based on nanomaterials, such as graphene, CNTs, and semiconductor QDs have shown unique advantages in high power output, stable signal, high speed and easy fabrication. Secondly, the sensitivity of THz detection in biological field has been effectively enhanced by novel sensors base on the combination of nanomaterials/nanostructures with metamaterials. Thirdly, utilizing nanoparticles as THz imaging contrast agents could greatly improve THz response. Finally, nearfield nanoscale imaging is promising to allow THz imaging with high resolution and accuracy.
With the growing applications of nanomaterials in biological sensing, increasing concerns about the biosafety of nanomaterials have been expressed by researchers 110. Toward biomedical applications by THz sensing based on nanomaterials and nanostructures, methods for accurate quantification of nanomaterials in biosystem are required to fill the gap in biosafety assessment of nanomaterials. To get a comprehensive understanding of nanomaterials in biosystem, quantitative and qualitative methods should be combined for the characterization of nanomaterials. It is worth mentioning that the interaction of nanomaterials and biosystem is still unclear 111, and the long-term impact needs to be further studied in the future. Nevertheless, studies on the biological effect of nanomaterials are in the preliminary stage, and much effort is needed for improving the bioavailability, stability, and biological compatibility of nanomaterials to reduce the biosafety impact in practical applications.
Considering its existing limitations of THz biosensing in practical applications, further research effort is still needed for the following aspects: 1. Novel structure design of integrating metamaterials with nanomaterials/nanostructures for THz biological applications is a promising method to achieve the biomolecular recognition with ultrahigh sensitivity. 2. Detection mechanism of THz biosensing based on nanomaterials needs to be further studied. Although lots of research achievements in this field have been obtained up to this

sections.heading: Journal Name ARTICLE
sections.text:
This journal is © The Royal Society of Chemistry 20xx J. Name., 2013, 00, 1-3 | 6
Please do not adjust margins
Please do not adjust margins
day, the principle of radiation-biomaterial integration is not elucidated with enough clarity. 3. Standard operational process and credible database of THz biosensing should be established, which would be beneficial to simplify the operating procedure and obtain reproducible results.
In conclusion, combining nanotechnology and THz technology is certain to be a very effective way to promote more extensive applications for biological sensing in the near future.
